notes.title: Probability Axioms & Conditional Probability
notes.content: Master axiomatic definition, addition/multiplication rules, law of total probability, and conditional probability as foundations for all later topics.
keyTakeaways: Kolmogorov axioms underpin all probability results.
Law of total probability decomposes events via partitions.
Conditioning changes the sample space; be precise with events.

resources.title: Penn State STAT 414 — Probability Basics
resources.description: Full online notes for probability theory

notes.title: Bayes' Theorem & Medical Test Paradox
notes.content: Use Bayes to invert conditionals and reason about posteriors; exam problems often feature diagnostics with sensitivity/specificity and low prevalence.
keyTakeaways: Posterior ∝ Likelihood × Prior.
Base rates matter; small prevalence yields counter-intuitive PPV.
Tree/box methods help avoid algebra mistakes.

notes.title: Mutually Exclusive vs. Independent Events
notes.content: Common trap: mutually exclusive events with positive probability cannot be independent. Exams ask for proofs/counterexamples.
keyTakeaways: Mutual exclusivity ⇒ P(A∩B)=0; independence ⇒ P(A∩B)=P(A)P(B).
If P(A)>0, P(B)>0 and A,B are mutually exclusive ⇒ not independent.
Use simple numeric counterexamples.

notes.title: Bernoulli & Binomial Distribution
notes.content: Binary trials; binomial counts successes across n i.i.d. Bernoulli trials.
keyTakeaways: Parameters: n, p; mean np; variance np(1−p).
Use for with/without replacement approximations (when N large).
Normal approximation valid if np and n(1−p) are large.

notes.title: Poisson Distribution & Approximation
notes.content: Model counts in a fixed interval with rate lambda; also approximates Binomial(n,p) when n large, p small.
keyTakeaways: Mean = Variance = lambda.
Approximation works if n>=20 and p<=0.05 (rule-of-thumb).
Useful for rare events: defects, arrivals, accidents.

notes.title: Normal Distribution & Standardization
notes.content: Symmetric, bell-shaped model central to inference; standardize to Z for probability lookups and CLT applications.
keyTakeaways: Mean=Median=Mode; fully defined by mu, sigma.
Central Limit Theorem drives many approximations.
Use z-scores for probability and CI calculations.

notes.title: Hypergeometric & Negative Binomial
notes.content: Hypergeometric models sampling without replacement; Negative Binomial models trials until r successes.
keyTakeaways: Hypergeometric mean = n(K/N), variance includes finite population correction.
Negative Binomial mean = r(1−p)/p for failures before rth success.
Use Hypergeometric for urn problems in recent CSS papers.

notes.title: Joint, Marginal & Conditional PDFs
notes.content: Work with bivariate distributions; integrate/sum to obtain marginals; derive conditionals and expectations.
keyTakeaways: Check joint PDF integrates to 1.
Covariance/correlation summarize linear dependence.
Conditional expectations often simplify computations.

notes.title: Point Estimators: Bias, Consistency, Efficiency
notes.content: Exams test definitions and comparisons among estimators; show unbiasedness/consistency with expectation/limit arguments.
keyTakeaways: Bias = E(theta-hat) - theta; consistency: theta-hat -> theta in probability.
Efficiency compares variances of unbiased estimators.
CRLB provides lower bound under regularity conditions.

notes.title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE)
notes.content: Derive likelihood, log-likelihood; take derivative and solve; use for exponential/normal/Bernoulli etc.
keyTakeaways: MLEs are often asymptotically normal and efficient.
Log-likelihood simplifies products to sums.
Regularity conditions matter for properties.

notes.title: Confidence Intervals for Means & Proportions
notes.content: Compute CIs using z/t depending on σ known/unknown; for proportions use normal approximation or exact when needed.
keyTakeaways: Use t with unknown σ and small n (normality assumed).
Two-proportion CI uses pooled/unpooled depending on test.
Interpret CI correctly: interval procedure coverage, not probability for parameter.

notes.title: Hypothesis Testing: z vs t (1-sample, 2-sample, Paired)
notes.content: Identify the correct test by data type, σ known/unknown, and pairing; show steps: hypotheses, test statistic, p-value/critical region, decision.
keyTakeaways: z for known σ or large n; t for unknown σ small n.
Paired t uses differences; independent t uses pooled/unpooled.
State assumptions (normality/independence) explicitly.

resources.title: UCLA IDRE — Choosing the Right Test

notes.title: Chi-Square: Goodness-of-Fit & Independence
notes.content: GOF compares observed to expected; independence uses contingency tables; ensure expected counts large enough.
keyTakeaways: df: k−1 for GOF; (r−1)(c−1) for independence.
Use Yates' correction sparingly (small 2×2 tables).
Report residuals to interpret cell contributions.

notes.title: ANOVA (One-Way): Assumptions & Interpretation
notes.content: Compares multiple means; partition variance into between/within; follow up with post-hoc tests when significant.
keyTakeaways: Assumptions: normality, homoscedasticity, independence.
F = MSB/MSW; significant F ⇒ not all means equal.
Use Tukey HSD/Dunnett for multiple comparisons.

notes.title: RCBD, Latin Square & LSD Test
notes.content: Blocking increases precision by removing nuisance variation; Latin Square controls two blocking factors; LSD is a simple post-hoc procedure.
keyTakeaways: RCBD: blocks × treatments; analyze via two-way ANOVA without interaction.
Latin Square: treatments arranged so each appears once per row/column.
LSD controls Type I error per pair; Tukey/Dunnett control family-wise error.

notes.title: Simple Linear Regression: OLS & r²
notes.content: Fit y=β0+β1x+ε; interpret slope, intercept, R²; check residuals for model adequacy.
keyTakeaways: Add constant in software explicitly (statsmodels).
Diagnostics: residual plots, normality, leverage/influence.
Confidence vs prediction intervals differ.

notes.title: Multiple Regression & Diagnostics
notes.content: Extend to multiple predictors; watch multicollinearity; use partial slopes and adjusted R²; conduct global and partial F-tests.
keyTakeaways: Check VIFs and condition indices.
Nested F-tests compare models.
Influence measures: Cook's distance, DFBetas.

notes.title: Correlation vs. Causation; Partial/Multiple Correlation
notes.content: Interpret correlation carefully; compute partial correlations controlling for other variables; exams ask definitions and interpretations.
keyTakeaways: Correlation ≠ causation; confounding can inflate/deflate r.
Partial r quantifies relationship net of other predictors.
Use r vs r² appropriately.

notes.title: Sampling Methods: SRS, Stratified, Cluster, Systematic
notes.content: Design affects precision and logistics; exams ask comparisons and procedures.
keyTakeaways: Stratified improves precision when strata are homogeneous within, heterogeneous between.
Cluster sampling reduces cost; increases design effect.
Systematic is simple but beware periodicity.

notes.title: Sampling Distributions & Finite Population Correction
notes.content: For sampling without replacement from finite N, adjust variance by (N-n)/(N-1).
keyTakeaways: E(x-bar) = mu; Var(x-bar) = sigma²/n * (N-n)/(N-1).
Know when FPC applies (n/N > ~0.05).
CSS papers test derivations.

notes.title: Index Numbers: Laspeyres, Paasche, Fisher Ideal
notes.content: Core price index formulas; Fisher is geometric mean of Laspeyres & Paasche; common in CSS questions.
keyTakeaways: Laspeyres uses base quantities; Paasche uses current.
Fisher (superlative) balances substitution bias.
Be able to compute and interpret with small tables.

notes.title: Marshall–Edgeworth & Walsh Indices (Pakistan CPI Context)
notes.content: Advanced bilateral indices examined in CSS 2024/2025; know definitions and when used; connect to PBS CPI methodology.
keyTakeaways: Marshall–Edgeworth weights by average of base/current quantities.
Walsh weights by geometric mean of quantities; close to Fisher.
Cite PBS methodology when discussing CPI construction in Pakistan.

resources.title: IMF — Basic Index Number Theory (Walsh etc.)
PBS — Methodology of Price Statistics (2015-16 Base)

notes.title: Vital & Demographic Statistics: GFR, TFR, NRR
notes.content: Definitions and computation for fertility/reproduction rates commonly tested alongside index numbers.
keyTakeaways: GFR: births per 1,000 women (15–49).
TFR: average births per woman given age-specific rates.
NRR adjusts for female births and mortality.

notes.title: Descriptive Statistics: Skewness & Kurtosis
notes.content: Go beyond mean/variance to shape measures; exam MCQs ask sign interpretations and relationships among mean/median/mode.
keyTakeaways: Positive skew: mean > median > mode.
Kurtosis describes tail weight (not just 'peakedness').
Use moment and quantile-based measures.

notes.title: Nonparametric Tests: Sign, Wilcoxon, K–S
notes.content: Distribution-free alternatives when normality fails; know when to use and how to interpret.
keyTakeaways: Sign/Wilcoxon for paired/one-sample medians.
K–S compares distributions (continuous).
Less power than parametric when assumptions hold.

notes.title: Time Series Basics: ACF/PACF & ARIMA Overview
notes.content: Recognize autocorrelation; use ACF/PACF to suggest AR/MA orders; know ARIMA vs exponential smoothing.
keyTakeaways: ACF tail-off & PACF cutoff → AR; reverse for MA (rule-of-thumb).
Difference to achieve stationarity before fitting ARIMA.
Use diagnostics: residual ACF, Ljung-Box.

resources.title: Penn State STAT 510 — Applied Time Series

notes.title: Pakistan Data Sources for Practice (CPI, Surveys, Bulletins)
notes.content: Use authentic Pakistani datasets to practice index numbers, regression, and time series.
keyTakeaways: PBS publishes CPI methodology, monthly indices, and bulletins.
Use CPI time series to build index/forecast questions.
Cite source/series definitions in answers.

notes.title: CSS Statistics Exam Strategy: Syllabus Mapping & Past Papers
notes.content: Align prep with FPSC syllabus; practice with descriptive papers (2023–2025); simulate timed solutions with stepwise reasoning.
keyTakeaways: Download official syllabus and past descriptive papers.
Map each topic here to past questions (2000–2024).
Show assumptions, steps, and final numerical answers.
